input:
1. A 34-year-old male presents with progressive weakness and muscle wasting in his distal lower limbs, first noticeable in his early twenties. He reports frequent tripping and difficulty running, alongside numbness and tingling sensations in both feet. On examination, there is marked atrophy of the anterior tibial muscles and mild pes cavus deformity. Deep tendon reflexes are reduced in the lower extremities, and sensory testing reveals decreased vibration and pinprick sensation distally. His family history is significant for similar symptoms in his father and paternal grandfather, suggesting a hereditary pattern. Electromyography shows signs of axonal neuropathy, while nerve conduction studies reveal reduced amplitudes consistent with axonal loss rather than demyelination. Genetic testing confirms a mutation in the GARS1 gene, confirming autosomal dominant Charcot-Marie-Tooth Disease Type 2g. Supportive treatment including physical therapy and orthotic devices is initiated to maintain mobility and delay progression.
What brings you in today?
output:
THINKING: The patient is asked why they are here today, probably feeling a bit unsure and worried about their symptoms, maybe even embarrassed. They might struggle to fully explain what's been happening or how they're feeling now. I should keep it simple, honest, and focus on their main concerns without overloading details.

ANSWER: Well, I’m 34, and I’m a guy. Lately, I’ve just been feeling more weak in my legs and feet, and I trip a lot more than I used to. It’s been pretty confusing because I also feel tingling and numbness down in my feet, and I don’t really know why all of this is happening now.

input: 1. A 34-year-old male presents with progressive weakness and muscle wasting in his distal lower limbs, first noticeable in his early twenties. He reports frequent tripping and difficulty running, alongside numbness and tingling sensations in both feet. On examination, there is marked atrophy of the anterior tibial muscles and mild pes cavus deformity. Deep tendon reflexes are reduced in the lower extremities, and sensory testing reveals decreased vibration and pinprick sensation distally. His family history is significant for similar symptoms in his father and paternal grandfather, suggesting a hereditary pattern. Electromyography shows signs of axonal neuropathy, while nerve conduction studies reveal reduced amplitudes consistent with axonal loss rather than demyelination. Genetic testing confirms a mutation in the GARS1 gene, confirming autosomal dominant Charcot-Marie-Tooth Disease Type 2g. Supportive treatment including physical therapy and orthotic devices is initiated to maintain mobility and delay progression.Can you tell me more about how these symptoms have been affecting your daily life and if you've noticed anything else unusual or different recently?
output: Well, I guess it’s been pretty hard sometimes. I trip a lot more than I used to, even just walking around, and I feel like my feet are kind of weird, like numb or tingly. Lately, I’ve been feeling more tired and unsteady, especially when I stand for a long time. It’s also messing with stuff I used to do easily, like running or even just being on my feet all day. I don’t really know if there’s anything else that’s different, but I keep worrying about if it’s gonna get worse or if I should be doing something different.

input: 1. A 34-year-old male presents with progressive weakness and muscle wasting in his distal lower limbs, first noticeable in his early twenties. He reports frequent tripping and difficulty running, alongside numbness and tingling sensations in both feet. On examination, there is marked atrophy of the anterior tibial muscles and mild pes cavus deformity. Deep tendon reflexes are reduced in the lower extremities, and sensory testing reveals decreased vibration and pinprick sensation distally. His family history is significant for similar symptoms in his father and paternal grandfather, suggesting a hereditary pattern. Electromyography shows signs of axonal neuropathy, while nerve conduction studies reveal reduced amplitudes consistent with axonal loss rather than demyelination. Genetic testing confirms a mutation in the GARS1 gene, confirming autosomal dominant Charcot-Marie-Tooth Disease Type 2g. Supportive treatment including physical therapy and orthotic devices is initiated to maintain mobility and delay progression.Can you tell me more about when your symptoms started, how they have changed over time, and if you've noticed anything else that seems to trigger or worsen them?
output: Well, I guess it started when I was in my early twenties, kind of slowly. At first, I just noticed I was tripping more and having trouble running, but it didn’t seem like a big deal. Over the years, it’s gotten worse, especially in my feet—they sometimes feel numb or tingly, and my legs get weaker. I don’t really know what makes it worse or better, it just kind of happens. Sometimes walking a lot makes it worse, but I can’t really tell what’s triggering it.

input: 1. A 34-year-old male presents with progressive weakness and muscle wasting in his distal lower limbs, first noticeable in his early twenties. He reports frequent tripping and difficulty running, alongside numbness and tingling sensations in both feet. On examination, there is marked atrophy of the anterior tibial muscles and mild pes cavus deformity. Deep tendon reflexes are reduced in the lower extremities, and sensory testing reveals decreased vibration and pinprick sensation distally. His family history is significant for similar symptoms in his father and paternal grandfather, suggesting a hereditary pattern. Supportive treatment including physical therapy and orthotic devices is initiated to maintain mobility and delay progression.Can you tell me more about how your symptoms have been evolving over time, and whether there are any other changes in your health or daily activities that you've noticed?
output: Yeah, I guess it’s been gradually worse — like, I trip more often now and have trouble keeping my balance, especially on uneven ground. My feet feel kind of numb or tingly all the time, and I sometimes get these weird shocks or pins and needles. It’s made things harder for me to do, like walking or even standing for a while. I haven’t noticed any new health problems, but I just feel tired or a bit off more than before. Sometimes I worry about what it all means.
